Award.AwardTitle: Collaborative Research: Sustained Observations of the North Pole Environment to Characterize Ongoing Arctic Change
Award.AbstractNarration: This award supports the continuation of the aerial hydrographic surveys component of the North Pole Environmental Observatory (NPEO) as part of the Arctic Observing Network (AON) and the Study of Environmental Arctic Change (SEARCH). During the annual aerial hydrographic surveys a number of tasks will be completed: (1) conductivity/salinity, temperature, dissolved oxygen and nutrient profiles will be measured in the water column; (2) water samples will be retrieved and returned to the laboratory for analysis of a variety of tracers [salinity, Ba, alkalinity, dissolved oxygen, nutrients, delta O-18]; and (3) a variety of ice-based drifting instruments will be deployed for other AON projects, including ice mass balance buoys, ice-tethered profilers and atmospheric pressure buoys. The "Intellectual Merit" of NPEO rests on its foundation of successfully tracking change in the air-ice-ocean system since 2000, and obtaining data that will help to answer the question "have a combination of long-term trends and decadal variability driven the Arctic Ocean to the brink of a new seasonal ice regime?" The "Broader Impacts" of NPEO center on enabling the scientific efforts of other investigators, and educating the public about environmental change in the Arctic. NPEO improves the scientific infrastructure by providing scientific data, developing new observational methods, and providing operational field support to other Arctic researchers. NPEO continues to take advantage of the cachet that the North Pole provides for generating many avenues for informal education and outreach. NPEO maintains a Web site, participates in various talks and demonstrations at the annual Polar Science Weekend at Seattle's Pacific Science Center, and will sponsor a booth at the SACNAS (Society for Advancement of Chicanos/Latinos and Native Americans in Science) conference aimed at broadening participation of under-represented groups in careers in environmental science.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Scientific merit:  The North Pole Environmental Observatory (NPEO) program started in 2000 as a research project designed to study the rapid, ongoing changes in the Arctic Ocean by measuring the physical and chemical properties of waters in a key region:  the central Arctic Ocean.  A major circulation feature of the Arctic, the Transpolar Drift, transports water through the study region.  The alignment of this large current was found to shift in response to changes in atmospheric forcing. Shifts in the alignment of this current were also related to changes in the composition of the water.  For example, the position of a front separating waters of predominately Pacific or Atlantic origin was also found to shift according to atmospheric variations. The chemical measurements conducted on water samples collected from the study region were used to separate and quantify the various sources of water flowing through this region (e.g., river runoff from Siberia and North America, sea-ice meltwater, Pacific water, and Atlantic water).  Over the 15-year duration of the project, these measurements revealed large, annual changes in the distributions of these different water types, including a significant downward trend in the contribution of meteoric water and an upward trend in sea-ice meltwater in the study region between 2000 and 2012.  These measurements also revealed that a recent (2003-2010) increase in freshwater content of the Beaufort Gyre was largely the result of a diversion of Siberian river runoff from the eastern to the western Arctic Ocean.  Additional, sensor-based measurements of dissolved oxygen and nitrate conducted since 2007 were used to reveal marked changes in the chemical properties associated with the cold halocline layer of the Makarov Basin.  This project has supplied data that have been vital in describing important, system-wide changes in the Arctic Ocean over the last 15 years.  Without these data, our understanding of environmental change in the Arctic would be largely incomplete.


Broader Impacts:  Three Ph.D. graduate students have been supported as part of this effort.  The project has also supported domestic and international collaboration through efforts to improve scientific infrastructure for research in the central Arctic.  Sharing scientific data and field expertise as well as helping with operational support (deployment of buoys and other autonomous platforms) and collecting additional samples of snow, water, and ice has been a key element of the project.  Outreach efforts have included the NPEO website, museum activities, and numerous media interviews.  The website receives an average of about 1,800 hits per day and provides a forum for the public to ask our scientific team questions about the Arctic.  The NPEO team at UW contributes to the annual Polar Science Weekend at Seattle's Pacific Science Center with talks and demonstrations. This effort targets families and K-12 school classes. We install a small NPEO ice camp display. The lectures and demonstrations describe the role of the Arctic in global climate and reprise material given in grade school visits illustrating basic science.  Media interviews have resulted in news articles and programs, a highlight of which included taking a reporter from the New York Times to the Pole, resulting in news stories and one book for young adults.  However, the most important broader impact of NPEO is satisfying the observational data requirements of the Study of Environmental Arctic Change (SEARCH) and Arctic Observing Network (AON). NPEO has made data collected during the project widely available. These data are needed to track and understand Arctic changes to anticipate or mitigate their effects on the global environment and society.
